title: 103_hr5023
content: The "Citizens' Tax Relief Act of 1994" reduces the lowest rate of income tax for individual taxpayers from 15% to 12.5% for taxable years starting after December 31, 1994. Additionally, the Act repeals the increase in basis of property acquired from a decedent. The "Citizens' Tax Relief Act of 1994" repeals Section 1014 of the Internal Revenue Code relating to the basis of property acquired from a decedent. It amends Section 1015 to treat property acquired from a decedent as acquired by gift for basis determination purposes. The subsection determines the basis for property under the death tax adjustment, with limitations on the net appreciation and Federal estate tax rate. The net appreciation is the fair market value minus the initial basis. The aggregate death tax adjustment applies to any estate. The aggregate death tax adjustment is calculated based on the net appreciation of properties and the Federal marginal estate tax rate, with a limitation that the amount cannot exceed the taxable estate. The Federal marginal estate tax rate is defined as the highest rate in the rate schedule, not less than 30 percent. The executor allocates adjustments among properties on the tax return. Conforming amendments are made to sections 1014 and 1015 of the Code. The amendments in section 1015 relate to the basis of property acquired by gift, from a decedent, or transferred in trust. These changes apply to decedents dying after December 31, 1994. Additionally, there is a phase-in of capital gains tax on inherited property. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to set the maximum capital gains rate for taxpayers with a net capital gain. The tax imposed shall not exceed a certain sum based on taxable income and rates. Additionally, there is a provision for a tax on net capital gain from property acquired from a decedent after December 31, 1994. The tax rate on net capital gain from property acquired from a decedent is determined based on taxable income and rates. The applicable percentage varies depending on the taxable year, ranging from 10% to 25%. Taxpayers can elect to mark-to-market property acquired from a decedent. The amendment treats property described in paragraph (1)(B)(i) as sold at fair market value on the first day of the taxpayer year, with any gain or loss recognized on that day. This amendment applies to taxable years ending after December 31, 1994. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL EXCLUSION OF GAIN ON SALE OF PRINCIPAL RESIDENCE ACQUIRED FROM A DECEDENT. The amendment adds special rules for a residence acquired from a decedent, exempting it from certain requirements if the decedent met them before death or if the taxpayer does. The amendment exempts a residence acquired from a decedent from certain requirements if the decedent or taxpayer met them before death. Effective after December 31, 1994, for sales and exchanges in taxable years after that date.
